study_plan_entry.title: Density functional theory for chemistry students

free_text.Learning outcomes: Students will learn about:[br/]1) Formal foundations of Hohenberg-Kohn-Sham density functional theory;[br/]2) The origin, advantages, and flaws of most commonly used approximations to the exchange-correlation functional; [br/]3) Main features of the computer implementations of the formalism used in chemistry;[br/]4) The state of development of theoretical and the prospects of their applicability in chemistry.
free_text.Content: 1)  Historical introduction to density functional theory in chemistry and physics.[br/]2)  Mathematical introduction to the concepts used in density functional theory (functional, functional derivative, extremum of a functional, constraints, Euler-Largange minimization).[br/]3)  Thomas-Fermi model of the uniform electron gas.[br/]4)  Basic theorems of density functional theory (Hohenberg-Kohn theorems).[br/]5)  Kohn-Sham Equations.[br/]6)  Local density approximation (LDA).[br/]7)  Generalized gradient approximation (GGA).[br/]8)  Adiabatic connection method (hybrid functionals).[br/]9)  Numberical implementation of Kohn-Sham equations.[br/]10) Relativistic effects and density functional theory.[br/]11) Linear-response density functional theory (excited states).[br/]12) Formal extensions: optimized effective potential, self-interaction correction, meta-GGA[br/]13) Conceptual DFT: reactivity indices.[br/]14) Some illustrative applications of Kohn-Sham equations.
free_text.Required prior knowledge: [li] basics of quantum mechanics (Schroedinger equation)[br/][li] Hartree-Fock method and LCAO approximation[br/][li] The concept of electron correlation
